data.text:
A short story of bad to worse.

Well our sailing season in the Med has finished; somewhat abruptly and in an unexpected fashion. Picture this: You‚Äôre out there in the Mediterranean, on this slick yacht called Coco with the sun smilin‚Äô like it‚Äôs got a secret. You‚Äôre chillin‚Äô, sippin‚Äô on a glass of somethin‚Äô fancy, thinkin‚Äô, ‚ÄúThis is the life, man.‚Äù

But then, outta nowhere, this seagull, this wise old seagull, decides to challenge your Zen. It‚Äôs like it‚Äôs been watchin‚Äô too many action movies or somethin‚Äô. This bird swoops down like a rogue missile, and you‚Äôre all, ‚ÄúNot today, seagull!‚Äù

You twist and turn, channelin‚Äô your inner Neo from ‚ÄúThe Matrix,‚Äù but here‚Äôs the kicker: beneath your feet, a banana peel appears. No kiddin‚Äô, a banana peel, the universe‚Äôs way of messin‚Äô with you. You slip, you slide, and BAM! You end up in a position you‚Äôd call ‚Äòextreme yoga.‚Äô

Your back goes, ‚ÄúSnap, crackle, pop!‚Äù and you‚Äôre there, stretched out like a pro gymnast, showin‚Äô off moves that haven‚Äôt even been invented yet. The crew on the yacht, my wife, she‚Äôs watchin‚Äô this like it‚Äôs a one-man Cirque du Soleil act. She can‚Äôt decide if I‚Äôm in pain or rehearsing for an aerobatics event.

This is how it went down‚Ä¶ Palma; October 13, it‚Äôs a Friday of all days. Piece that together and you‚Äôll understand the irony. We‚Äôve just arrived after a magical few weeks sailing Menorca, the Northern, Eastern and Southern coast of Mallorca; completed by a magical few days on Cabrera Island. Tied up safely at Reial Club N√†utic de Palma, basking in the reflected glory of the wonderful month we‚Äôve just had.

Time to clean the topsides, hull and get things packed up ready for our overnight sail back to Badalona in a few days where we are leaving Coco for a couple of months while we go back to New Zealand for a bit. Yeah it was pretty sore that night, that aging back of mine. But nothing to worry about. Couple of anti inflammatories; she‚Äôll be right mate.

And just like that, the next day, I become a legend, a name they‚Äôll never forget. You‚Äôre the guy who turned a seagull showdown into a back-bending masterpiece. It reminds me of something Matthew McConaughey would say; ‚ÄúLife throws banana peels at you, man, but you just gotta keep on cruisin‚Äô through the Mediterranean waves, and don‚Äôt forget to enjoy the ride!‚Äù Yeah well Matt my boy, I didn‚Äôt enjoy this ride brother‚Ä¶.

From here, everything goes completely off the rails. Monday; find Chiropractor. Tuesday; go back to Chiropractor. Karel from Axis Quiropractic was amazing, but I was unfixable. I can‚Äôt really walk at this point. Wednesday; long late home cooked lunch with our good friends Matias, Neus and Adela. Alex spends lunch lying prone on the couch on the couch self medicating with an amazing rum from the Canary Islands ‚Äì a gift from Adela. Sick of my lack of participation by this juncture, they take me to A&E at around 5pm. The hospital filled me up with intravenous pain killers with no effect. Back to the boat; MRI booked for the next morning. Cab back to the hospital the next day. Wise arse cab driver asks me why we didn‚Äôt call an ambulance. MRI takes place. I‚Äôm admitted to hospital.

At this point I had no idea I‚Äôd be spending the next 10 days in said hospital high on Morphine and a cocktail other opioids. They give me 3 ‚Äúinfiltrations‚Äú which are injections deep into the spinal cord. Fucking hideous. You can take your infiltrations and shove them up your nether regions! And I know know that morphine makes you constipated. Badly. How do regular uses deal with that one!

Still can‚Äôt walk. No legs since October 16. Living on about 3 hours of interrupted sleep every night. I‚Äôm like a pin cushion with multiple IV lines dangling out of my arse. The prognosis? I‚Äôve got a squished disk and a bit of degradation in L4 / L5 (that I had no idea even existed!). The hole in the side of my spine where the nerves come out is so restricted that it‚Äôs squeezing the poor wee thing like a python trying to get through the eye of a needle. No wonder I can‚Äôt walk. The pain is horrific.

After a week and no real progress it‚Äôs time for a change of tack. My wife has had enough of managing me, the yacht (while it‚Äôs been blowing 45 knots in the marina), a bunch of Spanish speaking doctors, fighting the insurance company and all the logistics involved in dealing with a medical emergency in a foreign country. She‚Äôs exhausted; I‚Äôm exhausted and in chronic pain.

She met Sarah and her family on the yacht Elation next door in the Marina. They are from Canada and fate smiled. Sarah is involved in this area of medicine back home. After some research she tells us that Barcelona has some of the best back surgeons in the world in a clinic called Teknon. Sarah was a gift, an angel in our time of need.

It‚Äôs Wednesday; I‚Äôve been flat on my back for a week. We swing into action and hit the internet, the phone, the fax, email, telex. I mean shit, I even dispatched a carrier pigeon to Teknon in Barcelona! We were desperate. We hit the jackpot. One of their top back surgeons, Dr Gilete, could make an additional slot for me at the end of his surgery day on Friday. We had 12 hours to get there. And I couldn‚Äôt walk, let alone get to an airport and get on a plane.

By midday on Thursday we‚Äôd found a helicopter medivac transfer from Palma to Barcelona with an ambulance at each end to get me to and from the airports. We lifted off in about 40 knots of crosswind late on Thursday afternoon and flew towards a very moody and dramatic sunset over Barcelona. We were running late and I wondered if we‚Äôd make our touchdown before dark. We didn‚Äôt‚Ä¶

A quick meeting with the doc that evening confirmed everything we‚Äôd known. They had to go in and hack some of the spine off to free everything up. Lovely. From there everything moved incredibly quickly. Check into the hospital at midday; X-rays and ECG‚Äôs. a review of the MRI and by 4pm I was being prepped for surgery.

Now I need to mention at this stage that this is the fist time I‚Äôve ever been in hospital; ever. I‚Äôve never had surgery before. I have a fear of needles. So how was I? Shitting myself was the medical term for my current condition.

The surgery was about two and a half hours, but it took them a couple of hours to wake me up. I was so high on the cocktail of ketamine and god knows what else, and I was having such a good time, I refused to come around. ‚ÄúAlex, Alex‚Äù I kept hearing off in the distance. I ignored them for as long as I possibly could. But then they gave methadone. That was worth waking up for. By the time I got back to my room at 10:30pm my wife was worried sick and I was off my face.

No sleep that night. I was like an English teenage in Magaluf after a night with the guy on the corner selling cheep pills and bags of white powder (you‚Äôll need to read my last post for that inside joke).

I‚Äôm two days post operative today. I walked pain free for the first time this morning. I walked (slowly) out the front door of the hospital and felt the sun on my face and the wind in my hair. I cried. Tears rolled down my face.

Where to from here? Hopefully I would have outstayed my welcome in hospital by Tuesday and they‚Äôll kick me out. That‚Äôs almost two weeks stuck in a bed! Unreal. It seems like a blur but I‚Äôm just super excited that end is in sight.

We‚Äôll settle down in Barcelona for a couple of weeks to recover and get ready for a flight back home. My wife has been in 5 different hotels in the last 6 days. She‚Äôs had enough of moving around! We still have to get Coco relocated from Palma to Badalona, hopefully mid this week before the next bad weather comes through. I mean if you had the option of a beautiful place in the world to recuperate, wouldn‚Äôt you choose Barcelona???

We‚Äôll leave her with Nautor Swan Global Services there for a couple of months and then I‚Äôm desperately hoping we can come back in February and sail her down to that wonderful group of islands about 50 miles off the African coast and the Western Sahara, to the winterless Canary Islands, and explore Tenerife, Fuerteventura, Grand Canaria, Lanzarote, La Palma, La Gomera, El Hierro and finally our favourite, La Grasciosa.

From this day on, I think my crew will affectionately refer to me as ‚ÄúThe Mediterranean Split Specialist.‚Äù It was a pain in the back you‚Äôd never forget, but the memories of that comedic ordeal would forever be etched in my mind ‚Äì and in the logbook of the yacht‚Äôs unforgettable moments.
